articles.summary: British firms are set to ramp up investment in artificial intelligence over the next year. Almost 60 per cent of firms are already embracing AI, according to Lloyds Bank's Business Barometer survey. Four in five early adaptors are already enjoying a boost to productivity.

articles.title: Google's new robotics AI can run without the cloud and still tie your shoes
articles.author: Ars Technica
articles.summary: Google DeepMind has revealed a new on-device VLA (vision language action) model to control robots. Unlike the previous release, there's no chatbot version of the VLA model available.   Google announced Gemini Robotics earlier this year and has revealed the new VLA.

articles.title: Sam Altman Is Heavy on the Promise, Light on Problems with Coming Singularity
articles.author: Michael Morris
articles.summary: OpenAI CEO Sam Altman is optimistic about the future of artificial intelligence. He claims that the benefits of AI will be enormous and that the future can be vastly better than the present. But society is already adopting AI technology at a rapid pace. There are problems with the 'alignment problem' and making sure there is wide distribution so that everyone can 'plug in'

articles.title: Anthropic wins ruling on AI training in copyright lawsuit but must face trial on pirated books
articles.author: Richard Drew
articles.summary: A federal judge ruled that Anthropic didn't break the law by training its chatbot Claude on millions of copyrighted books. Anthropic must now go to trial over how it acquired those books from online 'shadow libraries' of pirated copies. Javascript is required to be able to read premium content.

articles.title: US judge backs using copyrighted books to train AI
articles.author: FABRICE COFFRINI
articles.summary: A US federal judge sided with Anthropic regarding training its artificial intelligence models on copyrighted books without authors' permission. The company's training of its Claude AI models with books bought or pirated was allowed under the "fair use" doctrine in the US Copyright Act.

articles.title: Arizona educators seek balance in AI use among students, educators
articles.author: Stacy Mantle Mail
articles.summary: As of June 2025, only 25 U.S. states have released official Kâ€‘12 AI/GenAI guidance or policies. Only 27% of school districts have official GenAI policies. Northern Arizona University's Arizona Institute for Education and the Economy released an updated framework for generative AI use in schools. Arizona's largest districts are adapting the guidance to local needs.
